trace.final_output:
Quick answer
The main factors are macro (interest rates, growth/inflation), company fundamentals (revenue/growth, margins, cash flow), sector dynamics (AI demand, semiconductors, cloud/SaaS economics), capital markets & investor flows, regulation/geopolitics, and technical/market-structure signals — each can move tech stocks differently depending on company size, business model and timeframe.

Core explanation — what to watch and why
- Interest rates & monetary policy
  - Why it matters: Higher rates raise discount rates for future earnings, which tends to weigh more on high-growth tech names that have earnings far in the future.
  - What to watch: Fed guidance, real yields, curve steepness. Data suggests rising rates compress growth-stock multiples; easing can support higher valuations.
- Growth & revenue momentum (company fundamentals)
  - Why it matters: Tech valuations rely heavily on expected growth. Revenue growth, guidance, and ARR/retention (for SaaS) drive investor re-ratings.
  - What to watch: Quarterly revenue, forward guidance, churn, gross margins, and free cash flow. Negative FCF can be normal for early/high-capex firms — context matters.
- Profitability & cash flow metrics
  - Why it matters: Margins and free cash flow affect sustainability and ability to invest or return capital.
  - Sector context: Software/SaaS typically have higher margins (20–35% SaaS), hardware/lifecycle businesses lower.
- Valuation vs peers
  - Why it matters: Multiples determine sensitivity to news. Tech/growth P/E ranges: mature/value 8–15; market avg 15–20; growth 25–40; high-growth tech 40–100+.
  - What to watch: P/E, EV/EBITDA, P/S and FCF yield compared to industry peers.
- Sector-specific demand (AI, cloud, semiconductors)
  - Why it matters: Structural trends (AI adoption, cloud spend, 5G) create winners and crowd flows. For example, AI accelerates demand for GPUs and cloud compute.
  - What to watch: Customer spend trends, product cycles, backlog, and end-market adoption metrics.
- Supply chain & input constraints
  - Why it matters: Chip shortages, logistics, and component availability directly affect hardware makers and device timelines.
  - What to watch: Capacity announcements, lead times, supplier comments (e.g., TSMC guidance).
- Regulation, trade policy & geopolitics
  - Why it matters: Antitrust, data-privacy rules, export controls (especially chip export rules to China), and cross-border tensions can alter addressable markets and costs.
  - What to watch: Legislative developments, DOJ/FTC actions, and export-control news.
- Capital markets & investor flows
  - Why it matters: ETF/active fund flows, secondary offerings, and IPOs influence liquidity and sentiment in names and sub-sectors.
  - What to watch: Fund flows into/away from tech ETFs, secondary issuance, insider buying/selling.
- Sentiment & momentum (technical factors)
  - Why it matters: Momentum, RSI, moving-average crossovers and volume can drive short-term price moves independent of fundamentals.
  - Confirmation to use (always check): volume trends, support/resistance, 50/200-day moving averages, MACD, and multi-timeframe checks — RSI can stay overbought in strong trends.
- Earnings, guidance, and surprises
  - Why it matters: Beats/misses and forward guidance tend to cause outsized moves in tech due to high growth expectations.
  - What to watch: EPS/revenue beats, margin trajectory, and management commentary on demand.
- Competitive dynamics & product cycles
  - Why it matters: Rapid disruption or a successful new product can change market share quickly (e.g., shifts in ad platforms, cloud offerings).
  - What to watch: Market-share data, wins/losses with major customers, product roadmaps.

Practical implications — different timeframes
- Short-term traders: Focus more on earnings, guidance, technical signals, flows and news (product launches, regulatory headlines).
- Medium/long-term investors: Emphasize fundamentals (growth sustainability, margins, FCF), secular trends (AI/cloud), valuations vs peers, and geopolitical/regulatory risk.

How TapeScope tools can help (next steps)
- Use the screening tool to filter tech stocks by growth, margins, P/S or FCF yield.
- Pull fundamentals for specific tickers (revenue growth, ARR metrics, FCF) and compare to industry peers.
- Check news flow and SEC filings for regulatory/geopolitical updates.
- Run backtests or scenario analyses to see how a strategy behaved in rate-rising vs rate-cutting regimes.
- Add names to a watchlist to monitor flows and earnings dates (you currently have no watchlist; add names you’re tracking).

If you want live data
- To fetch current metrics for a specific ticker, ask with the symbol (for example: "Get AAPL fundamentals" or "Show NVDA P/E and revenue growth"). I can then surface the latest available fundamentals, technicals, and news.
